current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text: To amend the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act to require transparency in the operation of American Health Benefit Exchanges.

sponsor.#tail: introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

committee-name.#text: Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Section 1311(c)(5) of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act/s:1311/ss:c/p:5

header.#text: Weekly Reports on Health Benefit Exchanges

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act/s:1311/ss:c/p:5/sp:A

text.#text: in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , by striking the period and inserting a semicolon; and
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act/s:1311/ss:c/p:5/sp:B

text.#text: in
by adding at the end the following:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: and make available to State governors, State insurance commissioners, and the public, a report  concerning consumer interactions with the Internet website maintained by the Federal Government for health insurance coverage (healthcare.gov or any subsequent Internet site (or sites) that is established in whole or in part by the Federal Government to facilitate enrollment in qualified health plans, the receipt of advance premium tax credits or cost sharing reduction assistance, or comparisons of available qualified health plans) and any efforts undertaken  to remedy problems that impact taxpayers and consumers, such report to include—

text.#text: not later than the first Monday after the date of enactment of this subparagraph, and each Monday thereafter through March 31, 2015 (or the next business day when Monday occurs on a Federal holiday), in coordination with the
a State-by-State breakdown of—
the number of unique website visits;
the number of web chat logins;
the number of individuals who create an account;
the number of individuals who enrolled in a qualified health plan or Medicaid;
the number of enrollees in each zip code; and
the level of coverage obtained;

a detailed description of the problems identified with website functionality, the actions that have been taken to resolve those problems, the identity of the contractors that are involved in such actions, the cost of such actions, how such actions are being paid for, and the names of the Federal officials responsible for overseeing the process; and
a description of the separate problems with the website, including problems relating to—
logging into the website;
enrolling in coverage;
transferring  to the State Medicaid programs;
the calculation of advance premium tax credits or cost sharing reductions;
eligibility for qualified health plans, advance premium tax credits, cost sharing reductions, Medicaid, or the Children's Health Insurance Program;
income or identity verification;
the transfer of information to health insurance issuers; and
consumer privacy and data security; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: and make available to State governors, State insurance commissioners, and the public, a report  concerning the federally operated customer service call center, including the number of calls received by the call center, the Internet website or enrollment problems identified by users, how many calls are referred to the
, how many calls are referred to State insurance commissioners, and how many callers enrolled in a qualified health plan through the call center.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Centers for Consumer Information and Insurance Oversight
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Centers for Consumer Information and Insurance Oversight

text.#text: not later than the first Monday after the date of enactment of this Act, and each Monday thereafter through March 31, 2015 (or the next business day when Monday occurs on a Federal holiday), in coordination with the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: is amended by adding at the end the following:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Section 1311(i) of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act/s:1311/ss:i

header.#text: Disclosure of Navigator and Certified Application Counselor Grantees

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , State attorneys general, State insurance commissioners, and the public a list of all navigators and certified application counselors that have been trained and certified by Exchanges, including contact information for all navigator entities and their partner organizations, including subcontractors. Such list shall be  updated by the
on a weekly basis through March 31, 2015.

text.#text: Not later than 5 days after the date of enactment of the

header.#text: Public availability of list of navigators

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall make available on the Internet website maintained by the Federal Government for health insurance coverage (healthcare.gov or any subsequent Internet site (or sites) that is established in whole or in part by the Federal Government to facilitate enrollment in qualified health plans, the receipt of tax credits or cost sharing reduction assistance, or comparisons of available qualified health plans) a list of all agents and brokers who have been trained and certified by the Federal Exchange, including their name, business address (if available), and phone number.  Such list shall be updated on a weekly basis through March 31, 2015.

quote.#text: Not later than 5 days after the date of the enactment of the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: is amended by adding at the end the following flush sentence:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Section 1312(e) of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act
